Recent Monitor editorials and letters have raised issues pertaining to the Bible. On Dec. 11, a writer requested a list of the "many things in the Bible (that) have been disproved." We really don't have time for that.
 
 We can all understand, however, that the Bible is a compilation of many forms of ancient literature drafted by scores of scribblers and poets, mostly unidentified, often written on animal hides. The average fifth-grader of today has a much more accurate world view than any biblical scribbler.
 
 The stories in the many and varied books are just that - fictional stories - as in literature. From God the creator, Adam and Eve, and Noah and his ark of Genesis to the Beast of Revelation, with the miracles of Jesus wedged in between, the reader is presented with an elaborate mythology - the truth value of these stories is negligible at best. Just as Moby Dick is a whale hunted by Captain Ahab, and Huck Finn and Jim rafted down the Mississippi, God and Jesus are literary characters in a great fiction.
 
 The main literary theme that runs throughout the biblical stories is human sacrifice and male genital mutilation. Christians of today base their faith on bible texts that espouse human sacrifice. This is what the cross means - human sacrifice. It is all part of the mythology and symbolism of the bible. Thankfully, none of it is real.

 Herman Melville fictionalised a true and horrifying incident concerning the whaleship Essex out of Nantucket. If you get chance, read The Whaleship Essex: The True Story of Moby Dick or one similarly titled.
 
 The above in no way supports Biblical accounts: what the theist so often fails to realise is that so many Biblical themes are repeated throughout history and across many cultures. A cursory glance at flood accounts lends credence to the notion of a world-wide flood, but if the flood occurred only 4000 years or so ago, why are the accounts, when examined, so disparate?
 
 As another example, there have been many Messiahs throughout history, all similarly described and predating Christ, all involving wise men of sorts, stars, astrology, virgin births, preaching, miracles, human sacrifice, death and resurrection etc. The Bible does not stand above or apart from any of these. It's a fascinating book from a historical and literary context, and for that reason should not be dismissed, but to shape one's life around it...
